section.title: Commands, Options, and Arguments
section.para: This chapter describes the recommended DocBook tags to use for commands, options, arguments, and other parameters related primarily to command-line examples and procedures. Exceptions are common, and each case must be evaluated individually. The purpose of this chapter is to provide a starting point for delivering consistent results as often as possible.

note.para: In all cases, refer to DocBook: The Definitive Guide and The IBM Style Guide for initial guidance.

section.title: Documenting Commands
section.para: Commands generally appear in two main scenarios: inline, as part of a general discussion or description of the command; or in a displayed block, as part of an example or procedural step. The second scenario often includes several command options that apply to the specific example or task.

In keeping with the philosophy of "never say never," commands almost always appear inside <command> tags. Even when used in <screen> or similar tags, commands need to be marked up to differentiate them from other text that may appear in a displayed block, for example, computer output. This is especially true because, according to The IBM Style Guide, commands should not be preceded by any sort of command prompt, for example a dollar ($) or number (#) sign. If they appear as part of body text, commands need to be differentiated from the surrounding text.

example.title: Marking up Commands in Body Text
example.para: Use the <command>ifconfig</command> command to configure network interfaces.
Use the ifconfig command to configure network interfaces.

example.title: Marking up Commands in Examples
example.para: Enter the following command to determine the status of the firewall:
Enter the following command to determine the status of the firewall: service iptables status
